content: The Act titled "Real Estate Investment and Jobs Act of 2014" provides an exception from FIRPTA for certain stock of Real Estate Investment Trusts. The Real Estate Investment and Jobs Act of 2014 amends section 897(c) of the Internal Revenue Code to provide exceptions for certain stock of Real Estate Investment Trusts, including an exception for stock regularly traded on established securities markets and an exception for stock held by a qualified entity. The Real Estate Investment and Jobs Act of 2014 amends section 897(c) of the Internal Revenue Code to provide exceptions for certain stock of Real Estate Investment Trusts. A qualified shareholder's investment in a real estate investment trust is not considered a United States real property interest unless an investor in the qualified shareholder holds more than 10 percent of the trust's stock. The Real Estate Investment and Jobs Act of 2014 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt certain stock of Real Estate Investment Trusts from being considered a United States real property interest. To qualify, the investor must not hold more than 10 percent of the trust's stock. Additionally, a comprehensive income tax treaty with the United States requires a qualified collective investment vehicle with a principal class of interests listed and regularly traded on recognized stock exchanges, maintaining records of shareholders. The term 'qualified collective investment vehicle' refers to an entity eligible for reduced withholding rates under an income tax treaty, even if it holds more than 10% of a real estate investment trust's stock. The text chunk discusses the requirements for an entity to be designated as a qualified collective investment vehicle by the Secretary, including being fiscally transparent or entitled to deductions for distributions to investors. Additionally, it mentions amendments to distributions by Real Estate Investment Trusts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include provisions regarding Real Estate Investment Trusts, specifying distribution rules and defining qualified shareholders. In determining whether a qualified investment entity is domestically controlled, a qualified investment entity can presume that stock held by a holder of less than 5 percent of a class of stock regularly traded on an established securities market in the United States is held by United States persons, unless the entity has actual knowledge regarding stock ownership. Additionally, any stock in the qualified investment entity held by another qualified investment entity is subject to certain conditions. Any class of stock regularly traded on an established stock exchange or held by a regulated investment company issuing redeemable securities is considered held by a foreign person unless the entity is domestically controlled. Stock held by a qualified investment entity is treated as held by a United States person if domestically controlled. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 states that stock in a qualified investment entity held by another qualified investment entity will only be considered held by a United States person if the latter entity is domestically controlled. This amendment adjusts the percentage threshold for foreign ownership. The amendments made by the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adjust the percentage threshold for foreign ownership in qualified investment entities. The effective dates for these changes vary depending on the type of disposition or distribution. SEC. 3 amends the definition of United States real property interest in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It excludes certain interests in corporations. SEC. 4 requires notification of FIRPTA status. Section 6039C of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to require United States real property holding corporations to disclose their status publicly. This includes notifying shareholders through Form 1099s, annual reports, and websites. The amendment to Section 6039C of the Internal Revenue Code requires United States real property holding corporations to publicly disclose their status to shareholders through various means, including Form 1099s, annual reports, and websites. Additionally, qualified investment entities are presumed to be foreign controlled unless disclosed otherwise, with penalties for failure to comply with notification requirements. The amendment imposes penalties for corporations holding US real estate valued at $1 billion or more, with a minimum penalty of $5 million and up to $10 million for intentional failures. Effective upon enactment of the Act. The amendment requires brokers to withhold FIRPTA on sales by shareholders owning more than a 5 percent interest. The amendment requires brokers to withhold a tax equal to 10 percent on certain dispositions of nondomestically controlled United States real property holding corporations. Exceptions apply to domestic qualified investment entities and real estate investment trusts. The amendment requires brokers to withhold a tax on certain dispositions of nondomestically controlled United States real property holding corporations. Brokers must have actual knowledge or should have known of their withholding obligation. Section 1445(b)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to clarify this requirement. The amendments apply to dispositions after the enactment of this Act. The amendment expands the definition of United States real property interests to include interests in regulated investment companies and real estate investment companies. This amendment applies to dispositions after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amends Section 245(a) to state that dividends from regulated investment companies and real estate investment trusts are ineligible for deduction for the United States source portion of dividends from certain foreign corporations. This amendment applies to dividends received from these entities on or after the date of the enactment of this Act.
